1.sofaString: FACTORY INSPECTION                 Analysis of Text of New Ordinances                 IMPORTANT STEP                 by Eleanor hinder in the NEWS                 The Chinese press on February 2 carried the full text of 20 ordinances which have passed the Legislative Yuan the                 appointment and duties of factory inspectors It -will be remember ed that the Chinese Government announced in December last that its Factory Law would become operative on February 1, 1931, and simultaneously regulations for the administration of the law were published No mention was made in these of provision for inspection but the duty was laid upon local authorities to carry out the law It was know however that the question of inspection had been in the thought of the Ministry and the ordinances which have now appeared provide the machinery for the actual carrying out of the Law The postpone ment of the date of application until August 1, 1931, coupled with the authorization of inspec tion gives to administrative authorities sufficient time to pre pare for enforcement From the point of view of the adjustments necessary for large factories and mills in the purchase of addi1- tional equipment in the financial problems involved and in facing changed marketing conditions six months is too short time But if wisely used the period will prove of great use in planning for wise procedure on the part of those upon whom will fall the duty of enforcing law From other recent publicity it would seem that it is the intention of the Chinese Government to place the responsibility for the administration of the Factory Law upon local authorities municipal authorities in munici and district authorities in districts It is presumed that Bureaux of Social Affairs will be specially charged with this duty and it is further assumed that this should involve bringing action for infraction into the courts where necessary But the actual factory inspection the instrument by which the local authorities can find out whether the law is being observed will be in the hands of inspectors under the Central Labour Administration Organ the Ministry of Industry It is presumed that inspectors must then be assigned to cities and dis tricts to work with the local authorities for inspectors are under the authority of the Central Labour Administrative Organ and must go where they are assigned to make regular and special inspections Responsibility for training these inspectors will rest with the Central Organ They must be chosen from those who have graduated from special indus trial schools or who have other skill and knowledge or have worked in factories for ten years How the Inspector Will Work Nine sub-clauses outline the fields in which the factory inspec tor is -expected to operate In cheeking workers' ages and the kind of work performed in checking hours of work rest and holidays leave for women at childbirth safety and health provisions accidents and health age of apprentices and their relation to the number of works record books and documents as provided in specified sections in the Factory Law and in other Labour legislation In most cases it would seem that his authority extends merely to inspection for example if there is contravention of the article which provides that ii the health and safety provi sions of the factory are inadequate the proper authority may require improvements within time limit the inspector must report to the authority in charge for action However certain amount of power for action is placed in his hands for he may issue instructions if the safety and health conditions call for imme diate improvement if orders are not obeyed he must report to the proper authority for action He may ask for assistance from the administrative organ of the -er of the police when he needs it The inspector must produce evidence of his identity when desiring to enter factory Thereafter he has right to ques tion clerical workers manual workers or labour union officers and he has right to inspect all records which the law states shall he kept Factories which refuse entry to an inspector are liable to fine up to 200 and those refusing reasonable information may be fined up to 100 It is apparent that inspectors will be used for the gathering of statistical information which is usually obtained by routine report channels in other countries It is of them that they shall quarterly reports covering statistics of factories and workers in different industries working hours in every factory conditions with regard to child labour safety anp health provisions accidents                 and illness and labour turnover This may be regarded as an excellent approach to the whole question of the gathering of accurate facts Penalties Provided factory inspector Bhall not take bribes or write false reports shall not reveal secrets of indus trial processes shall not create bad feeling between workers and management or occupy simul taneously other official position or engage in business For any of these offences he mqy be punish ed and shall if the offence is criminal appear in court In general the provisions cover well the work which it is appar ently proposed the inspector shall do date for the enforcement of these clauses will be announced With the responsi bility for administration remain ing in the hands of the local authority the duty of prosecution probably remains there also In Western countries factory inspec- tors have this power In initial stages of the implementing of law which may give room for dif ferences in interpretation the provision of an inspecting staff which is largely reporting agency is wise Here in China as elsewhere the inspector may become useful both to employer and to worker he can if he is wise establish good relations with each The announcement of this law marks an important step toward the much-to-be-desired goal of regulation of industrial employment
